s.text: Sun Ra's men believed in the myth of their leader's origins and, like him, waited to be rescued from Earth by alien spaceships.
(Oddly enough, he neglects to mention Sun Ra's apparent homosexuality, to which jazz aficionados refer as if it were common knowledge.)
In living with Sun Ra, Arkestra members renounced drink, drugs, and sex.
He and his associates weren't operating at the level of metaphor.
The saxophones cry balefully, the drums rumble ominously, the marimba echoes warmly--yet the combined effect is more curious than moving.
The saxophones cry balefully, the drums rumble ominously, the marimba echoes warmly--yet the combined effect is more curious than moving.
(Oddly enough, he neglects to mention Sun Ra's apparent homosexuality, to which jazz aficionados refer as if it were common knowledge.)

Declaring himself a conscientious objector to World War II, he directed a poignant appeal to the National Service Board: "I don't see how the government or anyone else could expect me to agree to being judged by the standards of a normal person."
